div.head: A Journal from New York towards Marseilles Marseille

div.p:
At eleven p m the steam boat
made fast to us and in a few moments we
left pier naunber number six North River Pier 6 was located on the east side of Manhattan Island where Battery Park City now stands. the boat left
us in East River we are now sailing down
the harbor shall not go to sea today as it
has the appearance of a storm and no wind
at all to speak of we have come to an anchor
on quarantine ground Probably the "Old Quarantine" off Tompkinsville, Staten Island, which was the site of New York Harbor's quarantine station prior to 1855, when the residents of Tompkinsville burned the quarantine hospitals to the ground in protest Barring Out Epidemics. It has commenced
raining very hard therefore there is no telling
when we shall get to sea. The Pilot is on
board and will remain untill until we leave
the harbor, Two of the sailors isare drunk
and have gone below.

This morning at six oclock
we got under way with a fresh breeze
from the Westard Westward See the appendix "Markup Guidelines" for information about how this edition treats Doane's spelling, which includes consistent use of idiosyncratic and archaic spellings, as well as outright errors. which is fair for us The
Pilot left at eleven oclock, I took my
book and lead pincel pencil and sat down to
write my journal the first mate came along
and says here is a gold pencil and pen
which I will give you it will be much
handyer handier for you

This morning when I arose I found
the weather quite good and quite smooth so I
sat down and went to work on some fancy work but
did not remain so long before the wind came
ahead and made it very ruff rough yesterday I was
seasick and unable to write,

It is now four o clock and I will tell
you what has occured occurred , this has been a torable tolerable fine
day The wind is south, the vessel goes one point
within her course, It has begun to cloud up, I think
we shall have some rain soon, We have two cats on
board, and they were quite wild so we put them
down in the hole, they have come out today for the
first time, and father is feeding them with fresh
meat trying to tame them,

This is much the same weather as
yesterday
altho although the wind is fair we are sailing seven miles
and a half an hour, last night it was a very
ruff rough and tedious with a heavy wind and squalls,
and a number of dishes broken, I think we shall
have another ruff rough night, my time is occupied in reading I
have not been on deck today, they are now
taking in some sail, it commences breezing,

Today is quite moderate the last two
days it has been blowing almost a gale, thursday
at half past eight oclock in the evening we hove
too to and remain so untill until morning, friday morning
at six oclock lost our stern boat and davits
and a number of things in the boat such as
cabbages fresh beef and a rocking chair,
mother and myselfe myself were a little seasick,
have not been untill until today.

This is a lonesome and gloomey gloomy
day enough, the wind is blowing very hard
from the south which is ahead for us, it
has increased sence since noon we are now under
closed reefed topsails, I think we shall have
to heave too to soon, if it does not subside, we
have now been out eight days and have
had not a pleasent pleasant day as yet, which is
very discourageing discouraging , The poor sailors are keep
wet, all the time as there is a heavey heavy sea,
and they wash over us continually, thy they are
now taking in more sail, mother has not
been up today, we have hove too to , we shall
have a bad night I am afraid.

This is quite a pleasent pleasant day we
have laid too to under small piece of sail
all night, and this morning at eight
o clock we set sail with a fair wind, I
have been doing a little of all sorts reading
sewing and etc etcetera , There is one vessel in sight
ahead, We are some dispionted disappointed in our cook
he is not very good, We have to do considerable
of his work,

This morning the wind was ahead but
at twelve o clock it came fair for us, we have
a fresh breeze which we are very happy to
have, at noon when they took the sun we
were in the Latitude of forty, Longitude fif-
ty, we are going seven miles an hour, the
men are busey busy doing various articals articles of work,
mother sits on deck reading.

The wind is just so we can
lay our course, with a very head sea and
unpleasent unpleasant weather with rain squalls, we are
one hundred miles south of the Grand bank,
we cannot expect very pleasent pleasant weather so
far north, this morning saw a Brigg brig standing
north, I have just been makeing making bread,

We are sailing along with a fine
breeze and fair, we have had several rain
showers but it has cleared off fine weather,
we are in company with a schooner bound
the same way as we are but we rather out
sail her, this afternoon we have killed the
pig

This is a wet foggy morning, but
what wind there is is fair, yesterday the wind
was asouth as useaul usual and very ruff rough , last night
at two o clock we hove too to
agian again , which make
three times, it is now raining, mother has
not got up as yet, father is quite unwell, I
think he caught last night as he was up
most of the night.

This morning the wind was
ahead, but at two o clock had a heavy
squall, and change of wind, and with
it a whirlwind, which just cleared our
stern, there was great confusion, mother and
myselfe myself did not see it, supposeing supposing it to be
nothing more than a squall, we are now
sailing with a fair wind going seven miles
an hour, it blows quite fresh we are under
closed reefed topsails a heavy sea.

The wind has been fair all day,
untill until now and what there is is ahead for
us, mother is reading, we have made but very
little progress this two or three days past.

This has been a calm day and not
any wind to speak off of , mother and myselfe myself
have been busey busy cutting a dress, after dinner
the steward came in and says now, Captain
I must tell you, I have just been down in
the forecastle, and my chest cover splat in half,
I think it is too bad. The Captian Captain & mate went
forward, and called all the men and asked
them but they all denied it, The Captian Captain says
they will have to pay for the chest, mother is ma-
king pan cakes for supper.

We have had a fresh breeze from
the north quite smooth, so I have been at work,
we are within a short distance from the Western
Islands, which is more than halfe half ways to
Gibraltar, they have just sung out Porpoises,
and they are preparing thy
the harpoon, they are
going to try to catch some,

This is much the same weather as
yesterday, not much wind. the Island of Flores
is still in sight. we are close in by it so we
can see the houses with a spy glass. today I
have finished my dress,

The wind is ahead so we cannot
go our course, we are under closed reefed top
sails, yesterday the wind was ahead also. We
have passed the Western Island. it is rather
ruff rough .

The wind is ahead, which
is not very pleasent pleasant , the wind has been ahead
for three days. Today we have been making a
chair out of a barrel, it is growing quite
moderate, I think we shall have a change
of wind soon, we have a sailor sick, has
not been on deck since saturday,

This has been a pleasent pleasant day, this
more morn ing the wind was ahead, but sence since dinner
it has changed so we can lay our course, we are
going seven miles and a half an hour, I have

We are sailing along with a fair
wind, this has been a busey busy day with us; mother
has been makeing making mince pies, Steward has
been cleaning the petions partitions in the cabin. and I
have been washing out some pocket handker-
chiefs, It is very pleasent pleasant , have seen two
vessel stering steering north, came close to them they
are now out of sight, There is but very little
wind.

The weather still continues plea-
sent plea-
sant and fair wind altho although not much, have
been becalm nearly all night, but this afternoon
it has breezed up and we are sailing six
miles an hour, there are several vessel in
sight, last night about dusk one of the
cats, had a fit, and the first officer said
she went under some of the water casks,
but we think she must have gone overboard,
as we have looked for her and she is not to
be found, I felt loth to part with her, as she
was an old sailor, she had been to Canton
and back,

We have a fair wind quite a fresh
breeze, so we are under close reefed topsails, have
passed a number of vessel, there are two in sight
now bound the other way, they have just sung
out Land Oh, It is the Cape St Vincent,
mother has a sick headache has not been up
today, only with the exception of having her bed
made.

Today we have the wind so we can
lay our course, last night had it very squa-
lly and a head wind, mother is better so she
is up, last night saw the Light house on
Cape St Vincent, tacked ship at eight oclock
stood off from the land, while we sat at
the dinner table we saw all the sailors
coming aft, the head one came up to the
door with a pan of potatoes in his hand say,
Captian Captain , I want to speak with you if you
please, he says Captian Captain do you think there
is potatoes enough for six men, there were nearly
half a peck, the Captian Captain said if you are not
satisfied with what there is pass in your pan
and go without any, and away the poor
fellows marched backed back , and had to eat
thier their beef without any potatoes, I was most
sorry for them, about two oclock while I was
busily engaged in reading, I heard an usuea
l unusual noisey on deck, by the time I got to the door,
the second mate runs up to the Captian Captain , and
says the first officer and one of the sailors are
fighting, he parted them, the sailor disobeyed
the mates orders,

We have been lying becalm all
night and today, which is too bad, mothe mother is
quite smart, the mate ored ordered the man he had
the troble trouble with yesterday, to go and scrap scrape the
mast, he said he could not not do it, then
the Captian Captain called him aft and told him
to stand there untill until he was willing to obey
orders, at noon saw a turkle in the water throw
the harpoon but did not succeed in getting
him, there are five vessels in sight.

It still continues calm last
night the sailor came to the Captain and
said he wanted to go to work so he went to
work, I hope we shall have no more troble trouble
for it is very disagreeable, I have been draw
ing a pattern to work a pair of cloth slippers,
the men have been painting the gig boat, there
there
are two vessels in sight, the wind is
breezing up fair which we are very glad to
have,

Today is moderate as ever no wind
at all and what there is. is ahead, this morning
when I arose the City of Cadiz was in sight,
so we could see the vessel in the harbor,
have passed a great many spanish fishing
boats,

We have been beating with a head
wind all the morning, but at two oclock
halled hauled round the yards, sot set studding sails with
a fair wind, and we are now sailing pleas-
ently pleas-
antly through the Straits, we are now abreast
of the town of Tarifa, there are four vessel
in sight, some bound in some out. We have been
very busey busy washing, we are now close to a
Spanish brigg. there has just been a boat along
side of her from shore to sell fish they have
just spoke tous and wanted to know if we wanted
any fish, we told them no,

We have another head wind again
today, it has been blowing quite hard, so we are
under close reefed topsails, have tacked ship twice,
last night at ten oclock passed Gibralter, Gibraltar,
there
are quite a number of vessel in sight, mother is
quite unwell with a sick headache, it is so
ruff rough it is enough to make any one ache,
I hardly know where I am myselfe myself
somtime sometimes ,
have had a rain shower, the wind is subsid-
ing, so they are making more sail, I have
been busey busy reading, we are now close to a
Bark.

It is quite moderate very little wind
and fair, for the last two day, we have experienced
heavy weather, with a head wind and blowing
very hard, the land is in sight, several vessel in
sight, have seen a Spanish Steamer, I have been
busey busy sewing,

We are beating with a head wind,
last — lay be calm all night we are in sight of land all
the way up the straits and it is very pleasant
when we have a fair wind, sence since dinner the
wind has increased, there is one vessel in
sight,

div.dateline: TusdayDoane mistakenly writes "Tusday"; 19 March fell on a Friday in 1852. 19.
div.p:
Today it is calm no wind and what
there is is ahead, we are close in by the land,
we have passed several fishing boat some
spoke tous and wanted to know if we wanted
any fisk fish . there are eight vessel in sight, this
morning one of the salors sailors came to father and
wanted a little sugar to make some save salve , he
carried it forward, and put it in theforecastle,
and when he went to get it, it was gone,
some of the sailors had taken it, the Captian Captain
called the sailors and asked them, but they
all deny it,

This is another calm day, this
morning the Captian Captain called me very early, as
there was a boat coming along side, they
wanted to know if we wanted some fisk fish ,
then asked for some tobacco, and bread, whick which
we gave them, then they went off, there are twelve
vessel in sight, a bark and schooner close to
us.

Today we have the wind ahead, it
changed last night, have tacked ship several
times this morning, I noticed one of the chicken
was lame, and when we caught them to put them
in the hen coop, we found the rats had eat eaten all
her toes nails off, we have any quanity quantity of them,
the sailors says there is one all white in the fore
castle, we have just passed an english English brigg
bound the other way, and we saw there were
two ladies on board, which was quite a rarty rarity to
to
us, as we have been out forty three days, and
have seen nothing but sky and water, and a
great deal of ruff rough weather, the wind is increasin
g, the Captian Captain
say says
we shall have a windey windy
night,

We have a little breeze from the
westard westward which is fair, the last two days have had
head winds and have made but little progress,
we are not but two hundred miles from the Rock
of
Giberalter Gibraltar and we can soon go there if we have
a good breeze have had quite a rain shower
today I have been busey busy knitting there are two
vessels in sight,

This day have had it very pleasent pleasant , and
a fair wind, and plenty of it. but it has now
nearly died away calm, we are nearly out of sight
of the Island of
Trifa Tarifa , We are now within 335
miles of Marseilles Marseille , and if we can only have a good
breeze, we can go there in two days, there is one
vessel in sight,

This morning it was quite calm.
but it soon breezed up ahead. have seen the
Island of Majorca. today we have been taking up
the state room carpets, and washing them. and
cleaning the paint the steward has been washing
the cabin windows, there are several vessel in
sight. they are now bracing up the yards,

There is not much wind as useal usual ,
she merely lays her course, about oclock a spanish
steamer came close to us, sot set her colars colors , and we
sot set ours, she is nearly out of sight, we have tacked
ship twice, I have been reading. and out on deck
most of the day, as it was too
pleasent pleasant to stay in the
house,

We have had a fair wind all day,
and a fresh breeze, we are going 7 miles an
hour, if this wind continues we shall get there
tomorrow morning, we are I suppose about one
hundred miles from there, Oh dear I hope we
shall, for this is fifty two days at sea which is
a long passage, and I am quite tired, We have
a funey funny steward, hardly know what to think
of him, sometimes he is all the time talking,
and laughing, to himselfe himself , he has buried his
wife, and mother thinks that is some ofthe couse
of it, today he has been cleaning the petion in
the cabin, and puting putting down the state room
carpets, while mother and
myselfe myself have been wa
shing out some stockings, and father has been
making out a manifest of the stores he has on
board, I hope when I write again we shall be
safe in the harbor of Marseilles Marseille ,

We are now in the harbor of Mar-
eilles -
Marseille , yesterday at three oclock took a pilot, and
last night at half past ten oclock came to an
anchor, where we now lay, as soon as we came in
sight of the fort, we had to put out the fire
lights, it has a beautifull beautiful
entriance entrance , Doane's entry, with its references to the harbor's "beautiful entrance," and views of the city, is very unlike John Murray's description fifteen years later in A Handbook for Travellers in France (1867). Commenting on the layout of the city, rising on hills around the port, he says the following: "From this disposition of the ground, the port becomes the sewer of the city, the receptacle of all its filth, stagnating in a tideless sea and under a burning sun, until a S. E. wind produces that circulation in its waters which the tide would do on other seas. The stench emanating from it at times is consequently intolerable, except for natives; and dredging machines require to be constantly employed to cleanse it" 476. this morning
arose very early, and went on deck to see
the City, the Captian Captain went on shore, thas gone
to enter and get a premit permit , Murray's Handbook provides this information: "near the harbour mouth, is the Consigne, or health office, where every thing relating to quarantine is transacted, and whence the permission for vessels to enter the harbour is issued. To this office the captains of vessels come to give an account of themselves (raisoner), and to show their bill of health. The council room contains a few paintings, chiefly having reference to the plague. . . . The subjects are all horrible, and the execution not good enough to compensate 477. in a short time he
came back and several Gentlemen with him,
to get the manifest of the cargo and stores, then
the sailors rowed the pilot on shore, at half past six
the Captian Captain went on shore to see about a cook
house, as we are not allowed to have any fire
or light, and the steward carried some coffee
with him for breakfast, they charge four frances francs
a day, which is eighty cent, they find the fuil fuel ,
water, and cooking utensil, so we made out
breakfast very well.

This morning, we came on shore
to board to American hotel. it is kept by a widow
lady, she is french. altho although she had been in New -
York a number of years and could speak very
good english English . It is hardly surprising that Doane's family chose to stay in a hotel catering specifically for Americans if they held beliefs such as those presented in Murray's A Handbook for Travellers in France : "The character of the people [in the Provence] appear influenced by the fiery sun, and soil which looks as though it never cooled. Their fervid temperament knows no control or moderation; ferocious in disposition, they are led by very slight religious or political excitement, on sudden impulses, to the committal of murders, assassinations, and other acts of violence unknown in the North" 430. It happened we feel fell in with a
Captian Captain Eliott and his family an old acquaintan
ce of ours which makes it very pleasent pleasant for
us, the house is stone and all the floors and
stairs. there is no one here but Captian Captain Eliott
besides ourselves, a Captian Captain and three ladys ladies —
passengers left yesterday morning, I will now
tell you what we had for dinner, beef soup
rost roast turkey, rost roast beef, boiled lamb, stewedchickens,
potatoes, and spinage spinach , for desert dessert pie, oranges, apples,
pears, figs, for tea we had preserved beef. boiled
ham, fresh pork. white bread. butter. olives. stewed
pears. frosted cake. and then the fruit as we had
at dinner think. we shall like itvery much.

This morning we eat ate breakfast at
half past seven, had boiled beef, stewed chicken, frid fried
pork, frid fried potatoes, bread, and butter, and this
afternoon, we have been out shoping shopping bought a
number of things, some things are very cheap,
and some very dear,

Today about noon, we saw a funerl funeral
pass here, which was quite a curiosity, it was
a very large procession five or six hundred,
when rich people die, they hire all Orphans Orphan
children, sisters of charity, all the people out of
the poor house, to go in the procession, the
hearse looked like one of a carrour carriages altho although
open it was trimmed with gold gilt fringe,
then all around the hearse was were little girls,
all the sisters of charity had candles burning
in theirs their hands, then the friends followed, this
afternoon I have been out to ride, went into
a garden. about two miles from here.

Today I have been to a dentist to
have my teeth filled, he first claned cleaned my teeth,
took all the tarter tartar off. he said I had one tooth that
must be filled, and two that the nerve must be
killed, they was were too far gone to be filled, but he could
kill the nerve so they would never trouble me,
he then put in the stuff which kills the nerves.
and said I must let it be untill until tomorrow, when I
am to go again, from there we went to walk
in a short time we came home, I happenedto
be looking out of the window, and saw another
funerel funeral pass, something similar to the other, only
the body was carried on a bear bier which was part
bleack black velvet and white lace, it was a young
man, on the top of the bear bier was a very hand
some bunch of flowers, it was carried by six
men,

Today I have been to the dentist but
he could not fill them as the nerve was not killed,
from there we went up to a very large arch, Probably the Porte d'Aix. Murray describes it thus: "The entrance from the side of Aix is by an Arch of Triumph, remarkable not for elegance of design, originality of elevation, or elegance of decoration. It was intended to commemorate the campaign of the French in Spain in 1823, but its destination is now changed to that of celebrating 'all the glories of France'" 476.
and on the sides were bueatifull beautiful engravings,
then we returned home,

Last night father came home lame,
a pain in is his foot, could hardly walk, it came
on all at once, it painedhim during the night,
this morning it was better, so he went on board
the vessel, and when he returned it was much
worse, so we sent for the doctor, he pronounced
it the gout, and ordereda bread and milk poltest poultice ,
and said it would soon be better, I have just
been out to ride, to a beautifull beautiful garden, enjoyed
myselfe myself very much,

Father is getting better, altho although last nightithe
was very bad, so we had sent for the doctor,
he said he must continue the poltis poultice , and
bath his foot in herbs, and if it was not better
this morning, he should apply Leeches. but it is
much better.

Yesterday afternoon I went out shop
ing ping , and while I was out I was taken with a severe
pain in my head, I came home went to bed,
and when the doctor came to father, he came
in to me, said I was a little feverish, ored ordered a
sweet, and to drink some herb tea, and today
I feel as well as euasl usual , and father is gaining
also,

This morning the doctor has been
and say father came rid down to the vessel,
think we shall go on board, and stop untill until his
foot is better, as he cannot go and come, and
Mrs Eliott goes on board of the ship today,
also as they leave on Sunday, we lay along
side of each other so we can go on board,
which makes it very pleasent pleasant ,

This morning after breakfast,
our first officer went on shore, and when he
came back, he said Captian Captain Eliott was in
prison, in a few minuts minutes
Mrs Eliott sent for
us fto come on board, we went and found Mrs
Eliott crying, it appears his cook and steward
got to fighting on the wharf, he stepped up
to seperate separate them, and the Captian Captain and steward
was carried off to prison,

We are still on board of the ship
abbelino, as the came
Captian Captain still remaines remains in prison.

This morning they have been
on board, and says he will be out this afternoon we have been
out on deck most of the day watching
for him, and about two oclock we saw them
coming, the Captian Captain and several other getle
men gentle
men , Captian Captain Eliott has gone shore to clear will
get away tomorrow morning,

This morning we got quite early to
see Mrs Eliott off, but they are not going as the
wind bew blew so hard, the steamboat would not
take them out, this afternoon we have been
on board again, stop untill until night,

Today we go back to our boarding
house, Captian Captain Eliott sailed yesterday, this
afternoon we have been to a chuch church , which
was built three hundred years before Christ,
the outsidelooked very ancient, more so then than the
inside as that had been rebuilt, there was an
organ that was made at the time the church, it
stood there for people to look at, there were as
many as fifty people there at time we were,
some were in the confession boxes, some
parying praying , some kissing the floor, there were
a great many paintings,

We came on board at nine
oclock in the evening, Mr Oulone a
french getlemen gentleman , Mr Gondon, the land
ladys son, and daughter, and sister came
on board with us, as we loave leave early in,
we went out on deck played on the
accordeon accordion , had some cake as we were
not allowed a light, they stopped
untill until
eleven oclock,

This morning at half past five,
all hands were called to hall haul out of the dock,
while halling hauling out some of the men happened
to see our cat on board of the bark that we
layed laid along side of, they put her in a boat,
then in a basket, and passed her up.
at half past seven the steamboat made fast
to us, and we are now biding bidding farewell to
Marseilles Marseille , and stering steering for home, the wind is
so we can lay our course,

Today we have a fair wind, and
fresh breeze, yesterday the steward was quite
sick, but he is better today, this morning

we lost two of our fowls, a hen and rooster,
they were out on deck, and got frieghten frightened
over board, and could not get them, this morn-
ing there was a brigg brig ahead of us could just
see her, we have come up with her and past
her,

It is quite pleasent pleasant , altho although a head
wind, sence since dinner the wind has increased,
and it is quite ruff rough , have tacked ship several
times, the land of Cape Palos is in sight,
this afternoon when they last tacked ship, one
of the men, was on top of the house and when
he got down, he broke one of the panes of
glass, in the cabin window,

We have the wind so we can lay
our course altho although it is not fair, I have been
busey busy sewing, it is very smooth, this afternoon
mother has been making donuts a short time ago
the wheel rope parted, there was great confus
sion confus
ion , there are seven vessel in sight, but we are
ahead of the fleet, Cape De Gata is in
sight ahead.

We are beating with a head
there are four vessel in sight bound the
same way we are, it is rather
ruff rough .

Today we have a fair wind sail-
ing along
pleasently pleasantly , we are forty miles from
the Rock, the men have been washing the house
so to paint it the first drying day, mother
has got a sore throat, I have been sewing all
day,

This morning father came in at
half past five and called me to get up and
see the Rock of Gibaralter Gibraltar , the city is on the
Rock and you can go all around it we did not
pass it in some time altho although we had a fair wind
but theythere was a strong current setting against
us, there are a great many vessel astern of us
I do not exactly know the number, all bound
out of the straits, except two which are beating in
this forenoon I have made four lemon pies,
at 12 oclock, left the land with a strong
breeze, going nine miles an hour, mother has
layed laid down as she has a sore throat, they are
bracing the yards, the wind is canting ing
ahead some.

We have a fair wind, quite a
little breeze, this morning I have been wash-
ing and ironing out some pocket handkerchief,
steward is making preperation preparation for it is mothers
birth day tomorrow, this afternoon they caught
a beniter bonito with the grains, there are several
vessel in sight,

I will now tell you what has
occured occurred this day, mother is forty two years of age
at eight oclock the colars colors were sot set , for
dinner we had boiled beef, and pork, preserved
beef, potatoes, pickels pickles , punkin pie, sugar cake,
nuts, raisens raisins , prunes, wine, lemon aid, our
sailor had a plum pudding, at three oclock
the steward call them all aft, and gave them
some wine and cake, they all wished mother
a toast you would have laught laughed to see them
some was so embarrased embarrassed they could hardly
get the words out,

We have had a head since
yesterday. morning, today they have caught a
porpoise, the men are painting the house,
I have been busey busy sewing and mending
stockings,

Today we have a fair wind which
we have not had for the last week, we are in
sight of the Western Island, it has been a
very
pleasent pleasant day. there is one vessel in sight
bound the other way.

The wind still continues fair
this morning there was a schooner in sight bound
north, we came up with each other, she sot set her
colars colors , and we sot set our, after she took in her colars colors ,
we saw a boat coming for us, we backed our
main yards, and sails, it was an american American
walemen whaleman , the boat came along, asked a few
question, and past passed up four letter one for the Cap-
tain, he did not open it untill until after the boat had gone
he found the Captian Captain had sent for a few
potatoes as he had one man sick with the
scurvy, we then hailed the boat and they came
back, we gave them some potatoes and lemons, That the Doanes provide both potatoes and lemons to the man suffering from scurvy is indicative of the larger debate in the mid-19th century about the causes and prevention of scurvy. Although it was widely accepted that lime and other citrus juices were preventive agents, sailors were said to be reluctant to drink the juice. A series of letters to the editor of the London Times in 1866 reveals the alternative preventives proposed by many doctors; significantly, "fresh succulent vegetables" as well as potatoes and "preserved potatoes" were thought to be a successful alternative that presented an easier pill for sailors to swallow King
Click Here to Read the Letters to the Editor
A series of three letters about scurvy written to the editor of the London Times in 1866
they thanked us very kindly, and went off
it was the schooner Antartic Antarctic of Provincetown
Captian Captain Snow, been out four months, they
are now bound to the Western Island,

We have a fair wind altho although near-
ly calm, and very pleasent pleasant , yesterday George
one of our sailors was taken with a severe
pain in his face but he is better today
This morning Tom was at the wheel and
asked him how George was, Oh, dear, I
dont know he lays in his bunk growling, they
are painting the outside of the ship a
short time ago they sturck struck a porpoise
but did not succeed in geeting getting him

Today we have a
fair wind and a fresh breeze going eight
miles an hour the reason I have not written
for week is because I have had nothing to
write it being the same thing every day
we are but a short distance from New
York and if we are favored with a good
wind we can go there in a week passed
one Ship bound to Europe

Today we have a fair wind sail-
ing five miles an hour have see a school
of whales and a number of black fish
I have been busy cutting out a smooking smoking
cape and
quilting the lining have seen two vessel bound
to the Eastward six oclock too in studding-
sail as the wind has changed and we can-
not lay our course

We have a head wind and
blowing quite hard have tacked ship
several times today the steward is making
preperation preparation to go in to New York today he is
cleaning the paint in the state rooms

Today it has been a foggy wet
and unpleasentunpleasant day the wind ahead this
morning come on soundings and the Captian Captain
went to fishing caught one cod fish but be-
fore they got him on on
board they lost
him this morning saw three ships bound
to the
Westard Westward

This morning there was a thick
fogg fog and very wet tand calm at twelve
oclock the wind breeze up fair for us and
the fogg fog cleared itup at two oclock set studdi
ng sails with a fine little breeze yesterday we
lay becalm and the weather very unpleasentunpleasant
and foggy, there are two ship in sigh sight bound to Westard Westward

div.head:
Journal of a Voyage on board the Ship
Commonwealth by Louisa A Doane
div.p:
The Ship is chartered by Howland
& Aspinwall to load with Coal at the Port and
go to Acapulco and discharge the Coal. She is
then chartered by Mr Bennet to proceed from
thence to Lobes Islands Lobos Island on the Coast of Peru and
load Guano The June, 1920 issue of National Geographic Magazine describes guano (bird or bat droppings) as a valuable commodity used as fertilizer. The high quantity of nitrates created larger crop yields. During the height of Peru's golden age of guano, ca. 1840 to 1880, Peruvians excavated over 20,000,000 tons of guano for export, creating around $2 billion in profits Coker 537-566. and return to Hampden Roads Hampton Roads for
orders whether to proceed to Boston New York or
Baltimore to discharge

The Ship is partly owned
by Messers Foster & Nickerson is 650 Tons and is
about Two years old and has good accomadation accommodation
for us

My Father is to command the Ship my
mother is a-going with with with us my Uncle William
Thacher is to go the Voyage as one of the sailors
and all the others of the Ships company is Stran—
gers

My Father and Uncle S M Nickerson has
bought a Piano which cost $289, with the
Stool and Cover my Father pays for one half
and Uncle the other and they have set it up
in the Cabin and they say I shall be welcome
to the use of it on the passage out to Acapulco or
to the Lobes Island Lobos Islands and then Father is to sell it
if he can and invest the procced proceed in Hides or
Horns or any thing he thinks best and bring
them to New York and sell them. he agrees to
not charge any freight on either the Piano or
whatever he invest the proceeds in. he then
agrees to divide the profit or loss on the Piano or
whatever the proceeds is invested in equal with
Uncle Sparrow

I shall now commence my Journal
and endeavor to write every day at 12 oclock M
and give a discription description of our Voyage record the
distance we run every day the changes of wind
and weather and whatever occurs on board
worthy of note and the time of arriving and
leaving our Port of destination

We left the Wharf
at 12. M with a Steam Boat along side to tow
us round to North River where the Ship is
detained on account of the Second Mates not
being on board

We are now anchored at Staten Island
in quarantine ground Calm one of the sailor
is quite sick in the forecastle and the rest
appears to be quite Sober. The second mate
came on board last night, he is about
half drunk has been so sence since he has been
on board. They are now furling the sails we
shall
remaine remain here untill until morning.

This morning at 5 oclock AM all
hands were called to heave up the anchor and
we proceed on our way for an hour when thick
fogg fog set in and we were oblidge to anchor

The wind is SouE yesterday at 2.
oclock PM we got under way and work down
the harbor in company with several other Ships
and at 5 oclock PM came to an anchor in
the lower Bay furled our sails and shall
remain so until untill morning This morning
at 5 oclock AM when we got under way and
drifted down by Sandy Hook with very little
wind at 8 oclock the Pilot left us and we are
now proceeding on our way very slowly We
are in company with the Ship R Coale bound
to San Francisco

Wind SSE which is fair for us and
we are going 6 miles an hour with studding
sails sot. The Ship R Coal is still in sight,
The sailors are busey doing various kinds of
work. The sick sailor remains about the same.

The wind still continues fair. This
morning came up with and passed the Ship
Blanchard which left the night before we
did, last evening the sailor had a severe
pain in his Breast, Father
applyed applied a mustard
plaster

The wind is the
same we are going 8 miles an hour rather ruff rough
This morning exchanged signal with an Amer—
ican Ship bound to the Westward. The sick
sailor is out on deck today for the first time
sence since we have been out and is picking
stitches out of a sail that they have ripped
poor fellow he looks bad mother is a little
sea sick today she says

Wind S'SE fair going 10.
miles an hour had a rain shower today I
have been playing on the Piano today for the
first time sence since
Tusday Tuesday as it has been ruff rough
and it was with much difficulty we could
set the sick sailor is gaining he is out on
deck to work

We have a fair wind blowing
quite and unpleasentunpleasant weather squally the last
day it has been calm no wind, there are
two vessel in sight bound to WEastward
same way we are one we are fast approach
when there are vessel in sight thWe have com
pany

Wind SSE fair blowing quite
hard and we are sailing with Studding
sails sot 7. miles an hour and we are going
fast from our native home. last night at
dusk passed a Brigg. Today hmother has
been washing father has been cleaning
out my state room and I have been
helping him so you see it has been a
busey busy day with us

div.dateline: Tusday Tuesday 12. oclock M Augt August 17th
div.p:
This morning I awoke and heard
an uneausl unusual noise on deck I dreessed dressed
my-
selfe my-
self and run up to the door to see what it
was and saw we had a very heavy squall
it has been squally all night at 3 oclock
in the night carryed carried away a Studding sails
Booms throught through the Second Mates careless-
ness he is not much it was in his watch
Wind fair. One Brigg in sight astern

For the last 24 hour calm and
pleasent pleasant weather and sailing now today they
are painting the house. Green and White

Wind so we can lay our course
rainy and squally the sailors are cleaning the
outside of forecastle to paint, my time has
been occupyed occupied in reading and knitting
it has commenced clearing offt off , think we
shall have good weather

Fine weather fair wind what
there is but nearly Calm. This morning father
caught a nice large Dolphin with the Grains
today I have been playing on the Piano most of
the day and sewing. the sailors are painting the
forecastle.

Head wind and Clam Calm tacked Ship
twice today, This morning saw a Bark ahead
standing the same way we were but two
sails sot father could not think what to
make of it thought she must be in distress
but as we approached saw it was a whaler We
have now come up with her, she is close to us.
She has a large whale along side, Today, father
struck a very large Dolphin but did not succeed
in getting him on board, mother and myselfe myself have
been making fruit Cake

div.dateline: Tusday Tuesday 12 oclock M Augt August 24
div.p:
We have a fair wind and blowing fresh
are in the Trades winds, have seen several Ships
standing North, The sailor that was sick, We
think fained feigned sick, as he was no sailor and did
not want to go work as he shiped shipped for an able
bodied seaman, He cannot go aloft nor work
on the rigging he is nothing more than a boy,
They keep him scouring muskets, looking after
the fowl and pigs and such work as that,

Wind the same, This morning at
4 oclock the first officer had some trouble
with one of the sailor this morning when
I went out to see the pigs I saw the
sailor way out on the flying Gibboon Jib boom
The jib boom is a relatively high support, located at the forward end of the ship supporting a top sail (the jib). Scraping was integral to ships' maintenance, but would have proved difficult while sailing, thus the task was reserved for punishment. scr—
aping it that was to punish him, The first
officer told one of the sailor to take the dog
and carry him between deck and tie him
as they had been painting the deck he did
so and this morning found him dead he
was hung by the line he was tied too to ,
and one of my kitten has had a fit father
gave her some Ether which brought her
out ofout out of the fit and she playing around
as common

Wind stills continues fair and fine
weather killed one of the pigs one vessel in sight
in sight
standing North, I have been reading
and playing with my kitten there they are very
playfull playful little things

This day fair wind altho although very ruff rough
a head sea, and the water is continually
washing over us, mother
layed laid on one Sofa
and I layed laid on the one to the to the
Leeward when the SShhip fetch a heavey heavy
lurch mother came over and the Sofa
on top of her I jumped up and her nose
bleeding freely, I was very much freighten frightened
I called for father at the tip top of my voice
he being on deck at time she did not hurt
her much hit her nose againts against the table
which cause it to bleed

dateline.note: Doane employs a superscripted "th" for all ordinal numbers. For the sake of readability, we do not report usage such as "2th" or "3th" as errors, nor do we superscript these ordinal markers.

div.p:
The wind has subsided and it
has become quite smooth, mother and
myselfe myself have been out on deck most of the
day as father is painting a carpet for the
entry on top the house,

Today the wind has been change
able in no particular point long at a time
unpleasentunpleasant weather have had a rain shower
and now it is entirely calm sails flapping
have passed a Schooner bound North

Wind ahead have tacked
Ship twice The sailors have all got on their
Sunday suit and are raading reading Tracts as
father sent them out some this morning
There has been a Ship in sight most of
the day bound the same way as we weare
but fog has set in and we cannot see
her

Wind moderate very hot this
morning had quite a rain shower father has
been over the bow struck one Porpoise but
did not succeed in getting him, This mo-
rning the second mate told me one of our
sailors knew the Rules of Music. he told
me some Notes I did not know It seems
strange that a sailor before the Mast can
play on the Piano he says his father is
a Professed teacker teacher of music

Fair wind quite a little breeze
while I sat out on deck the man at the
wWheel say there is Sharks astern and we
went and found two father got the Harpoon
sturck struck the large one but it would not enter
it then he got a piece of salt Mackerel
put it on the hook and caught the small
one the large one came again and he also
caught him they are very hard to kill
Jack one of the sailors got a stick of wood
to kill him and the harder he struck the
more he jumped and the Carpenter steps
up and says hold Jack I get the Mall Mell ,
I work the Longitude every today day
Longitud
e of 27 West. Latitude of 10 North.

In the night experienced
a heavey heavy squall accompanyed accompanied with rain and
lighting lightning struck us at 12 oclock In the
Second Mates watch, he did not call father
nor the first Mate but father happened to
wake up just before she struck us and found
he had not taken in any of Studding sails
carryed carried away one and tore a Number of the
other sails, The rain and carrying away of the
Studding sail awoke me, I Jumped out out of
bed very much frighten put on my dress and
run to the door found there, It was raining in
torrents, and all the windows, dead light and
Sky light were all open and before the
steward got afft It had rained in consider-
able you cannot imagine what a sight it
is to have a heavy squall at sea, The wind
whistling through the rigging and the waves
running high. father sing out to the tip top
of his voice so as to be heard to let go every
thing, It was soon over,. This is the second
time the Second Mate has carryed carried Studding
sails, Think he is not much experinced experienced
This morning when I arose I went out on
deck the first thing to see the sails. unpleasant unpleasant
weather. at 10 oclock AM thick fog set and it
rain very hard for about two hours steadey steady
full up all our empty Cask which was 7.
and the water standing on the deck 6 inches
deep, It was quite laughable to see the
sailors down in the Lee Scuppers setting on
one of the spars scrubbing there their cloth It has
stopped raining but cloudy

This morning the Carpenter
came in to altered alter the first officer room
to cut a door in the entry and close the one
in the Cabin. while his things were lying
in the Cabin father took up the Log Book
to look at it and found something wrote
there againts against him which ought not to have
been in that Book. It made father very angry
and caused loud talk,

Wind ahead blowing fresh
father has had several talk with the first
officer. and he appears very Ugly and wants
to have his own way, father has threatened
to put him off Duty he has a very bad
disposition Revengefull revengeful . I am most afraid of
him myselfe myself , We have a little Colered colored
Boy in the Cabin, and the Mate thinks he
has told father somethings which has caused
the trouble and he is down on him. The Boy
sleeps in the Main Hatch House, and when
he went to last night he went to the Cook
and asked him for his Boyeknife bowie-knife The Cook
asks him what he wanted it for he said he
was going to
carryed carried it to bed with him
and if the Mate touches me in the night
I will cut him with this knife if I am
throwed overboard for it in the morning

We have a head wind beat-
ing tacked Ship twice, This morning Father
had another occasion to talk with the first
officer, and appeared more Stubborn and Ob-
stinate than ever, I hope we shall get along
in Peace but we cannot tell what will be
it is a long time before we shall arrive
to our Destined Port.

Wind stills continues ahead
tacked Ship several times unpleasentunpleasant weather
it is growing quite Cool. killed one of the Pigs
have seen a Bark standing the same way
as we are, I have sewing as useal usual

We are now in the SE Tarades
Wind which is fair for us and we are
sailing along pleasently pleasantly with Studding sails
sot set one of the sailors is sick has sent in for
some medicene medicine , all hands variously employ-
ed in Ship Duty

Today the sailor is better.
The sailor that accquainted acquainted with Music has
been down in the Cabin showing me for two
hours, 6 oclock this morning saw a vessel
on the Lee Beem Beam , and when I arose we could
see her very plainly. a Brigg Brig at 10 oclock left
her out of sight astern seen one Ship,

This have been a very pleasent pleasant
day mother and myselfe myself have been washing
out a few pocket handkerchief. Two hours
in a day weI practise on the Piano, 6 oclock
this morning first Mate jumped from off' the
house and in doing sprant sprained his Ankle very
bad so he cannot bear step on it this after-
noon father has bound it up with Wormwood
and Rum he says it is very painfull painful

This morning I arose at 6 oclock
and went to practtiseing practicing
untill until 8 oclock
which is our breakfast time. We have a
Carpenter on board he has a house by him -
selfe him
self forward of the Cally Galley , We did not like
to have him to eat in the Cabin he being a
Foreigner and not knowing what he was
therefore he took his meals in his house.
he appaears very much of a Gentlemen Gentleman and
fathir father liking him told him he could take
his in the Cabin at the second Table, and
this morning he came he seemed very mu
ch embarrassed, the Cook say he told him
he was so shamed he could eat anything
he meat meant embarrassed, mother had not
left the table when he came in and he
asked the Cook if the Missis always sat
to the table,

This has been a busey busy day been
having the Store room painted in the lower
Cabin and also the water Closet, and
Mother and myselfe myself have been doing
over some Current currant Jelly they are now
painting some in the Pantry. I have
just been down in the State room and
went to the draw where we keep our
Bedding found every one wet and some
Mildew which supprised surprised me suppose the
water came in the Dead Light and went
throught through the Transome Transom into the Draw we
have put them in to soak, I work the
Chronometer time with father
evey every day.

There is but very little wind
I have been busey busy cleaning out the lower
Cabin It has been very warm There is
a Ship in Sight to the leeward of us we are
come up with each other father has just sot set
his Colars colors She sot set hers she is an Ameri-
can Whaler She is luffing down to us and
is quite close to us,

Last night at dusk
saw a Boat coming from the Ship came
along side A Gentleman came on Board and
Introduce himselfe himself as Captian Captain Taber
Ship Thomas Dickerson of New Bedford
and found he was a near Neighbor to us
he said he had some thing in boat if
we would accept of them we were welcome
to them We thank him. they then past passed
up four Punkins Pumpkins half a Bushel of Onions
and three Dozen Oranges, He has been out
Ninty Ninety days but has been in to the Cape
De Verds Cape
Verdes after Vegatables vegetables . has 90 Barrels of
Sperm Oil, Fitted out for four years Cruse Cruise
He stoped stopped to tea and the evening, We
gave him a loaf of Fruit Cake two
Tumblers of Current currant Jelly and one of Grape,
This morning when I arose Calm and
the Ship Close to us ahead, after Breakfast
went out on, and saw he had tacked Ship
and was coming down to us come close to
us, spoke us then tack Ship Father
ored ordered
the quarter Boat to be lower and maned manned
and went on Board the Ship after some oil
for the Binnical Binnacle Lamp as ours is very bad
it will not burn long at time, He stopped
on Board two hours or more and when
he returned, and the Captian Captain had sent
a Bucket of Oranges four more Punkins Pumpkins ,
beside given father a large can full of oil
he would not take any paid for it

We have had a
ruff rough night been lying Reefed Topsails had it
Windy and Squally this morning could just see
Ship astern But she has been rapidly approach
us has come up with us and is quite near
us so we can see the Captian Captain on deck. he
waved his handkerchief to us and an
apron in return and his hat,

We have had a stronge strong Breeze
carryed carried
Stodding Studding sails untill until two oclock PM
had some rain in the night and this morning
it has been raining and blowing quite hard
The Barometer is falling which signifys signifies a
storm, could not get the Sun it being thick
but by Dead Reckoning We are in the Lati-
tude of 24=00 Longitude 38=67. South of the
line

Wind still increasing
put one Reef in the Maine Main Topsail and
one in the Mizzen Topsail a heavey heavy sea
and it is continually washing over us
just had dusk, a sea came over the Mizzen
rigging and over the lower Cabin Skylight
at the same time the vessel fetching a heavy
lurch lifting the Skylight up there not being
secured and down come two Pails of water
I think wetting Carpet Transom Chusion Cushion
Piano Covering Table Covering then we had work
enought enough called the Steward and we man
aged to get the Carpet rool roll up and 8 oclock
called the Steward to secure the Sofas, and
called the Carpenter to secure the Chonom-
eter Chronom-
eter and Chest in father state room, at 12.
oclock in the night called all hands put
Double reefs in the Topsail at the same time
a Barrel of Peachs Peaches which was in the Maine Main
Hatch House gave way and went down in
the hole and also a can of Oil so there
is a mess Peach Oil and Coal, and it
rained torrents filled our empty Casks in a
short time, father was up most of the night
and Mother Steward and myselfe myself had as much
as we could do to look after the things in the
Cabins every thing given away, and the vessel
rooling rolling very heavey heavy ,

First of the last twenty
hours moderate and quite pleasent pleasant
untill until this
morning when it commenced breszing breezing so they
put Double reef in the foretopsail one in the
Main and fuled furled the Mizzen Topsail, there
are a great many bBirds, flying around
Father threw over some Salt Pork and there
any number of them along side. Father then
got a line, caught 6 Cape Horn Birds they
are white and black there their Wings are tipped
with white. A large number of Albatrosses have
been following the vessel, have succeeding in
catching two they are a very handsome Bird
when they were taken on deck they were preven-
ted from flying or making any snappish
salutation by locking there their wings they have
some bountiful Down upon their Breast We
plucked out some of the feather which were
of Pure white

Light breszes breezes most of
the day the Cabin boy got mad with the Cook
and when we asked him dto do any thing he
seemed very cross and would answer us up quite
sharp. This morning he had washed up the
Entry Oil Cloth Mother told him to wash out
the Mates Rooms, he had washed out the
first Mates Room and went into the Second
Mate when Mother happened to be coming
in from off Deck and found him Crying
said he had the Cramp in his foot and
he could not stand on it I ran down
down
and got the Opodeldoc "Opodeldoc" was a U.S. regional term for any (generally, alcohol-based) medicine or tonic. In Doane's time, it was probably "an alcoholic solution of soap . . . and camphor with some added essential oils," which could be ingested or rubbed on the site of injury Oxford English Dictionary. and the Mate
came in and bath his foot and told him
to get up and stand on his foot but he
would not in a few minutes we saw he was
making belive believe
father came in and told him
if he did not get up if in
hea minute he would
make him he jumped up quick I can tell
you and went about his work, one Ship in
sight to Leeward of us. She
sot set her Colars Colors and
we also sot set our in return. an American could
not mak make out her Name,

Fair wind last night
Father and the Second Mate had some ruff rough
words, Father
ored him to go over the side and
see to the scraping of some Barnacle. he went
over and went to scraping hmiselfe himself and when
he came on board he told he would not scrap scrape
of Barnacle it was not his place in the hearing
of, Father which made he very mad and had
talk, Father told him he need not do anything
more on board the vessel
untill until he was willing
to obey Orders. he went in his room did not
come to the table to suppur supper . and did not st-
and his watch, this morning father called
out of his room and told him to stand aft
of the Mainmast when it was his watch on deck
I think we have a great deal of trouble

We have a head wind Mr
Turner remains offt off Duty. This morning he
went to Father and asked his forgiveness and
said he sorry, said he was in a Passion
and he would do every thing he was told
to do after this. The Steward and Mother are
making Sausages as we kill one of ou our large
Pigs yesterday I have been busy sewing as
usual, The wind is increasing has the appe-
arance of a Storm I hope not as it is very
unpleasent unpleasant ,

Last night at 8. ocl-
ock all hands were called to reef Topsails
and called again at 11. oclock to Double reef
had a very night she Laboring very much
This morning found the Weather about the
same Cold and Stormey Stormy
altho athough the wind had
cease, so they took one reef out of the fore
and Main Topsail, Shiped one sea in the
night which came down the Skylight into
the two Cabins altho athough it did do much
damage came in the Enty Entry , birst burst open, the
Second Mates and went into the first Mats Mates
also and both of their Trunks were afloat in
the Entry.

Head Wind blowng blowing
quite fresh soon after dinner Mr Turner the sec-
ond officer was on the Forecastle deck doing
something he fell. and hurt him very bad
no Bones broken he has not been out of his
birth berth since it is very painfull painful have sot set up the Stove
in the Cabin, as it is very cold. This morning
at 4 oclock it blew very hard so thy they Double
reefed and put a reef in the Foresail did not
know but what we should loose the sails from
the yards

Last night at 11 oclock
all hands were called to reef Topsails, as it
was blowing very hard and raining a heavey heavy
sea Father was up most of night and Mother
came up and layed laid on the Sofa untill until he
came in. Mr. Turner is better so he is
attending to his Duty altho athough he is quite lame
this morning set more sail. Untill Until 10 oclock
when all hands were called to take in sail
carried away Gib jib before they got it in, I shall
be glad when we get around Cape Horn I
have heard a great deal about its being a
Dreadfull Dreadful place and I do not know what we
shall have to see before, we get around
We are in the Latitude 48=35. Longitude 59=37.
160 miles from the Falkland Island bearing
SSW of us

Fair wind fresh breeze
sailing along pleasently pleasantly 8 miles an hour a
School of Sperm Whales in sight we have had
a good breeze all night, This morning a
Bark in sight to Leeward standing the same
way we are rapidly approaching her this has
been a very pleasent pleasant day see the Sun set clear
the evenings is very
pleasent pleasant as the Twilight
is long It is light nearly 3 hours after the
Sun sets Latitude 53=48 Longitude 63=40

Wind still continues fair
we are going 8 miles an hour. Last night while
I sat at table reading I heard father sing out
Land Oh on the Larboard Bow not knowing
whether it was Tierr Del Fuego or Staten
Island and it being in the night Father
thought it not Prudent to run so they brace
up the yards and keep off from the Land. shor-
tened sail During the night this morning
the same Land in sight It is Staten Island
one Ship in sight bound the same way at
8 oclock took down Studding with a head win
d We can see the Land quite plain It is
very high and mountainous and we can see
the snow laying on the mountains The Ship
is fast approaching us she is now abreast has
sot set her Colars Colors . 12 oclock Land bearing W of
us

The ship is a
litle little ahead of us so we can see her Name it
is the Damascus of Baltimore two more Ship
in sight astern they are fast approaching as they
have a strong breeze and we have it calm
while we sat at the tea table Mr Turner came
to the door said the Ship had set her colars colors .
It was a Clipper Ship. This morning Calm
one Ship close to us astern she is now a
breast of us Father spoke her It the Ship Louisa
from London bound to Callao been out 76 days
all well There was a Lady and several
Childran Children on board. we were very much
pleased to see a Lady after being out 84
days and seeing nothing but men altho athough we
could not speak with her

It is still pleasent pleasant and
a fair wind little did I think we should
see such weather as this altho athough there is time
enought enough yet the Ship is still in sight which
6 vessel vesin sight including ourselves all bound
the same way at 6 oclock it breeze up and blew
fresh at 8 oclock left the Land with a strong
breeze going 8 miles an hour altho athough there is a
strong Currunt Current set against us This morning
two Ship in sight have had a fresh breeze all
night We ought to be up with the Cape soon
with this breeze

Fair wind as yet at
2 oclock AM Sung out Land Oh. Its It is
Cape Horn. The long dreaded Place It is pleas-
ent ant
altho quite cold, The Ship Damascus is close
to us Father and myselfe myself were busey busy work up the
Longitude when the first officer came to the
door and says the Wind had headed the Ship
off and she was braced Sharped. Father went
out on deck immediately when a severe wind
and Squall struck us and change of wind We
had all sail set and Studding Sails they did
not calle call the other watch but they were at there their
supper, and they burst open the door and came
out in a hurry It was quite Laughable to see
them altho it was no time to Laugh It was
heavy but soon over they braced up the yards
with a head wind leaving the land astern
There are all the Ship in sight that we were
in Company with the other day At 8 oclock
called all hands to Topsails Fathar Father stopped on
deck untill until 11 oclock and when he went below
he gave strict order if it blew fresh to call him
at 1 oclock shipped a heavey heavy sea which poured
down in the lower Cabin altho although the Skylights were
well secure. and some water came in Father happ-
ened to wake up and went on deck It was the
Second Mate's watch he had all sail set and
blowing very hard The Main Top Gallantsail
Sheet parted by that means tore the Sail they
called all hands to close reef Topsails, the nights
are very short when it came morning we saw
one Ship in sight a short distance from us,

The last three days
it has been blowing a gale of Wind and ahead
most of the time under Double and close reefed
Topsails. We are off Cape Horn Latitude 58=43
Longitude 68=30 South We are in company with
several Ship Ships last night just at dusk came
close to a Bark standing on the other tack
Mother and myselfe myself went out on deck to
her but the wind blew so hard and it being
cold we did not stop long, had a very tedious
night and it was with much Difficulty that
we could remain in oue our berths It blowing very
hard and the vessel labouring very much
one Ship in sight I have been busey busy knitting

Wind ahead beating
which is Discourageing discouraging at 1 oclock called all
hands to tacke tack Ship they had just got her
up before the wind when a heavy Squall came
and the wind blowing a Herrricane Hurricane they
took in sail as fast as Possible took in all
but the Main Topsails, had the Wheel lashed
altho there was a man there The wind howling
through the rigging and the waves running
high and washing over us continually the vessel
diving into the sea very deep at 6 oclock made
more sail to keep her steady as the vessel
was rooling rolling very heavy had several snow
shower this morning the wind was about the
same altho not blowing so hard one Ship
in sight to the Leeward of us under short sail
one of the sailors sick has sent in for medicine

The wind is moderate-
ing fast altho we are under reefed Topsails
some time in the night the Wind came around
fair. This morning a thick Snow Storm I step
ped out on Deck and the yards and sail were
covered with snow It is very cold. one Ship
in ahead we are fast approaching her I saw
two of the sailor had no mitten on walking
the deck there their hands looked as if they would
freeze I asked them if they had no mittens there their
reply was no I then came in and got an allold
pair of stocking and made a pair and father
anhad an old pair which he gave me and I
gave them to them they seemed very thankfull thankful
for them there is one sailor instead instead
of
wearing his stocking on his feet he waars wears them
on his hands for mitten The Ship is abreast of
us all the sail she has set is the three Topsails
firled furled and a Spanker

This is 11 days we
have been beating off Cape Horn have not
made but 200 miles towards our place of
Distination destination have had continual Gales of Wind
from the Westard Westward which is ahead, and the
poor sailor looke look
beatten beaten and tired out and
they have to be out on Deck and weathre weather it
all and the sea is washing over us I pity
them, I wish the Wind would come fair
and lets let us go along as we have some
distance to go yet.

The Wind is
the same but blowing very heavey heavy . The
Barometer is down to 28 where we may
expect a SW. Gale This morning at 2
oclock it commenced breezing and keep
increasing untill until 9 oclock and It blew
a perfect Gale, The seas running moun-
tains high and often breaking upon us
At 11 oclock Shipped a heavy sea which
carryed carried away Monkey Rail foward forward and
stove in the fore Hatch House breaking in
the forecastle Windows and filling it with
water also staving in the Gally Galley window and
door and filling it with water and shifting
the Coal between deck which gave her a
list they then called all hands to wear Ship
then all hands were ored ordered down in the hole
to throw up the Coal that had shifting, We
are now lying under small piece of sail

Have a head
wind as useal usual first of the day quite mod
erate one Bark in sight abreast of us stan-
ding the same way. This morning all
hands were called to take in sail as
it was blowing fresh It was nearly
half an hour before the first Officer came
on deck and when he did he went to
schooling one of the sailor sailors for nothing
at all father stepped up and asked
him what he was abusing that sailor
for he said he was not. Father told him
the sailor came when he was called and
that was more than he did. he gave Father
a very saucy reply and from that it lead led on
to a long talk and almost came to blows
Mother and myselfe myself ran out on deck
very much frieghten frightened I never heard a
man talk so insulting he told Father he
should try to get along untill until we got in
then he should make Fathe Father all the troub-
le he could, he also said if mothe mother had
not been on board she would have been
a widow which was as much to say he
would have killed Father. He says he
will kill the Cook when he gets in He
is a very Dangerous man

I sat on the
Sofa reading I saw mother holding on to her
head and she asked me if the vessel
roolled rolled I told her no she said her head
went round and round my uncle
happened to come in and I told him
to tell Father to come in he did so he had not
been in house but a few minuts minutes when she
gave a screech and fell off the Sofa. I was
very much freightened frightened The two Mates came
in and helped hold her supposed it was a
Fit caused by excitment excitement she soon came
out off of
out it but her head pains her very
much. The weather is very bad the wind
blowing a gale from the Westard Westward . We are
Hove too to
Mother is better

The wind is
still the same blowing fresh. The first mate
is confined to his bed with the Rheumatic
Pains one Ship in sight to the Leeward of
us standing the same way.

Weather the same
the Ship is in sight astern The Mate is
still in his room The Cabin boy came
to mother and told her he saw a Pistol in the
Mates Trunk as he went there to get some artical article
of clothing and he saw a Double Barrelled
Pistol and the Balls also. We told Father of
it and he said he should the room search-
ed and if there was any thing of the kind
he should take them, The Second Mate
and Carpenter have search searched his room but
could not find it suppose he has made
way with it. This morning he is about
the same says he is in a great deal of Pain

It is smooth.
The Mate is some better, This morning Fair
wind sent up the Royal yard and sent the
sail and sot set Studding sails It seemes seems new
to us to have a Fair Wind as it has been three
weeks that we have had it blowing a Gale
of wind and ahead I hope we have got
into
pleasent pleasant weather The Carpenter oversee
the Mates wath watch We are four Degree North of
Cape Horn Latitude 50=32. Longitude 729=21

This has been a
pleasent pleasant day. Fair Wind have had it so for the
last two days The Mate is so he goes out on deck
I can precieve perceive it grows warmer, This morning
calm a school of Black Fish sound the vessel
I have been clearnig clearing up the lower cabin as
it got all in a confussion confusion
sence since we have had
the ruff

Throughout out
these 24 hours fresh breezes Stormy weather
and heavey heavy sea at two oclock AM kill the
large Pig after it was dressed weight 200
Pounds

Fine weather
The Carpent Carpenter is making some alteration in
Father State room in the lower Cabin all
hands are to work The Cook is trying out
Lard Steward washing Table Cloths and
two ordinary sailors cleaning Muskets I
have been Practising Practicing on the Piano as it ahas
been three week sence since it was opened as we
have been in bad weather all the time and
was not able to sit and Practis practice this morn-
ing one of my kittens had a Fit she was
very stiff and her eyes set, I thought she
had gone for it, but Father took her up and
rubbed her and she came out of it.

Wind the same
and pleasent pleasant quite warm. The Cook has been
cleaning the Paint in the lower Cabin. This
morning took down the Cabin Stove, We are
now abreast of Talcahuana Talcahuano

Moderate lay
becalm all night and most of the day This
morning saw a large Shark along thru threw the
Harpoon and Grains but did not succeed
in catching him soon after the Shark
disappeared one of the sailor jump overboard
to swim round the vessel but he had not
more than got into the water before Father
sight of him and called to him to come on
board as quick as possible if he did not to
behave a Shark to eat him up he came on
board

The last week
have been becalm untill until yesterday when we
took the South East Trade wind which is Fair
for us At 8 oclock AM saw a Ship to the Lee-
ward of us standing the same way, Father
Luffed up to her and bore down to us It was
a large Clipper Ship Spoke her. It was the
Maylay of Salem from Boston by the way of
Valvaraiso Valparaiso been out 92 days Bound to
San Franciso San Francisco had passenger on board saw
a Lady she did not go ahead of us much
but went off more to the Westard Westward This morn-
ing out of sight have a strong breeze going
8½ miles an hour, four months today
since we left the wharf which is a long
time to be to see sea time begins to go heaveyly heavily

Fair wind and
pleasent pleasant weather going 7 miles an hour very
smooth sailing you would think you were in a
house it is so smooth This morning shortly after
beeakfast breakfast
Father ordered the First Mate to do some
kind and he gave him a very insullent insolent reply
which caused Father to get in a passion, He
put him off Duty Father he could not come to
his table any more as he felt then towards
him, so ends this day, and with some trouble

Mate still off duty This
morning one of my kittens had several fits and
died in on one and one of the sailors sew her up in
canvass and tied a piece of to her and threw her
overboard I was very sorry to part with her as
she was a great deal of company always on the
Sofa playing with me and sleeping in my work
basket

Fair wind first part
of the day pleasent pleasant
lettar later
thinck thick and rainey rainy . Two Ships
in sight one ahead stering steering the same way as we are
think she must be bound to the same Port The
other Ship is coming towards, We are 600 miles from
there which is but a short distance if we are favored
with good winds about five days sails,

dateline.note: Judging from Louisa's assertion that she hasn't written in her journal for one week, she incorrectly writes the date as December 28 when it should be December 30, which fell on a Thursday in 1852.

div.p:
It has now been one
week sence since I have written and I have not much
we have it Calm and head winds and only a three
breezeLouisa refers to a force three, or gentle, breeze on the Beaufort Scale. at that we lay becalm now, are within
165 of ou our
Port but I do not know when we are going
to there if we are becalmed here much longer I
have been anticipating that we should have been in
before now but we cannot goet there unless we have
wind and that we cannot make, Last hnight one
of the sailor had a fit soon came out of it, This
morning little more breeze This sailor look if
was sick his eyes are very wild from the
effects of the Fit I have been busey busy writing of a
manifest of Stores for Father. at 12 oclock one of
the sailor came to Father and asked him if he would
give him some molasses as he had none. Father
told him he saw the molasses that had alowed allowed them
and if he had none he could not help it he went
off muttering to himselfe himself told Father if he would not
give him any he would steal it. Father then put
him in irons and told him he could remain
there untill until he would come to him and asay he
was sorry for what he had said and would try
to do better for the future and eat what was allow
ed him.

It is the first
day of January and a very hot day it is The Ther
mometer stands at 86 Degress Degrees in the Shade we
cannot find a cool place anywhere it is stark
calm have made but very little progress for the
last two days distance 125 miles The sailor
is still in irons he is not allowed to go for-
ward or to converse with any one stays on the
house days and sleeps under the boats The sick
sick sailor still remains bad last night he came
to the cabin door to see Father & anMother they went to
the door he said he thought he was going to Die
as he had the Chills upon him they told him
Oh no his Pulse was good that he must
be freightened frightened he said perhaps he was as he
had been hearing the sailors talking about the
Panama Fever In 1856, William Buel wrote in The American Journal of the Medical Sciences that the Panama Fever was understood to be caused by "decaying vegetation, stagnant water, and a high temperature" 820. Buel further notes that the Panama Fever derives its name from the isthmus of Panama, which was supposed to be its place of origin, and that the fever usually developed around the time ships rounding Cape Horn arrived at the port of Acapulco 821.along the Coast they gave him
some medicince medicine , At 11 oclock I was woke up
by the Crys Cries of my kitten I went up and found
the Second Mate had brought her in the entry
she was in a fit is just alive now I have
made her a bed on deck and lays on it
she cannot stand

dateline.date: Sunday 12 oclock M Jan 2 the nd

div.p:
Still calm and warm
as ever The sailor is much better so he is at work
last evening Just at dusk the sailor that was in
Irons came to father and asked his
forgivness forgiveness
said he was sorry for what he had said but the
sailors put him up to it said he should be on
his guard and not speak for no one but himselfe himself
then the Irons were taken off and he went about
his work Father and the Carpenter have caught
several small fish had them cook for supper they
were very nice. This morning quite a little
breeze my kitten is no better I think her back
is broken as she cannot move

dateline.date: Monday 12 oclock M Jan 3 the rd

div.p:
At 2 PM sot set
Studding with a fair wind. This morning soon
after breakfast I went out on deck and the men
were over the side scraping the vessel when the
Second Mate called Caloing one of the sailors from
offt off the stage to come on deck He did so and first
we saw they were fieghting fighting we were very much frie-
ghten fri-
ghtened when thought prudent he parted them. The
Second mate whipped him, Then the sailor went to
talking very saucy heto Father he was then secured
in Irons, and will remain there sometime, have just
heard the joyful shout of Land Oh joy beamed in
every countenance you must imagine what our joy
what our joy was after being to sea 148 days we are
about 60 or 70 miles offt off

Fair wind calm through
the night. and this morning ahead one Schooner
in sight standing the same way we are close in to
the Land, my kitten appears to be about the same no
better think she cannot live one of the men has
thown thrown her overboard as I thought was cruel to let
her lay and suffer so.

Calm all night
as useal usual this morning a little breeze standing in
for the Land one Bark in sight standing to the
Westard Westward found it to be a whaler they lowered the
boat and came on board left some letters she
was from Acapulco
cruseing cruising along the Coast The
sailor still remains in Irons confined in the Second
Mate room

Fair wind and
a fresh breeze sailing along with studding sails
sot set close in by the land at 2 oclock AM one
of the large Steamers passed us bound to San Fran
sisco cisco she was loaded with passengers a strong
breeze throughout the night. and this morning
saw the entrance of the harbor of Acapulco at 9
oclock PM took a Pilot. at 11 oclock PM
came to an anchor in the harbor oppisite opposite the City
as they called it but it is not much of a City
compoised composed of a few mat houses altho although it is
better than being than sea. The costom custom house
office has been on board and also the american
man war man-o-war boat and the Merchant father has
gone on shore with him brought offt off some
fruit Pineapples and orangs oranges .

This morning

LochiboLoch Libo

At the time, abstaining from food was a typical treatment for dysentery, though Doane's father seems to suggest that the man died from this treatment, rather than from the disease. According to the Water Cure Journal, "fasting has a great power over diseases of this kind. We have cured many a case of bad dysentery at sea, depending principally upon entire abstinence from all food and drink other than pure water" Rogers 79. and

In A Treatise on the Physiological and Therapeutic Action of the Sulphate of Quinine (1882), Otis Frederick Manson, M.D., professor of physiology at the Medical College of Virginia, describes in detail the history and uses of quinine. The medicine was made from a bitter alkaloid found in cinchona bark. In the 19th century, quinine was used to not only dispel fever, but also to treat pain and swelling caused by malarial infections. Manson describes in detail the effects of quinine on a patient: "I gave him twenty grains of quinine . . . and next morning, on awaking, the pain had vanished, and the inflammation of the muscles of the jaw and general swelling of the face had diminished to such a degree that he could eat his breakfast" 41

Island In Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life During a Four Months' Residence in the Valley of the Marquesas (1847), Herman Melville writes, "The Marquesas! What strange visions of outlandish things does the very name spirit up! Lovely [women]—cannibal banquets—groves of cocoa-nuts—coral reefs—tatooed chiefs" 3. Though the islands were beautiful and exotic, Melville reports that people feared them: "Within the last few years American and English vessels engaged in the extensive whale fisheries of the Pacific have . . . put into the commodious harbor which there is in one of the islands; but a fear of the natives, founded on the recollection of the dreadful fate which many white men have received at their hands, has deterred their crews from intermixing with the population sufficiently to gain any insight in their peculiar customs and manners" 4. Melville hoped to discover more about the Marquesas in order to "withdraw the veil from regions so romantic and beautiful" 4

Thompson Gill describes the ingredients and cooking of Pilot Bread: "Sea-biscuits, pilot bread and plain crackers, those without 'shortening' of butter or lard, are simply flour and water worked into a tough dough and baked instead of being air or sun dried as macaroni and vermicelli are. They are usually made of northern grown wheat, containing more starch and less gluten than macaroni" 55. In a seemingly fictional story entitled "At Sea" by A. Jones, Pilot bread is used not only as a diet staple but also as a remedy for seasickness: "Now, if you will just nibble pilot's-bread for a day, and sip champagne—a table-spoonful at a dose—you will probably escape. Seasickness is all a notion anyhow" 44. come to open it found it was halfe half
