the Ship hope they will not come on board
again as it is very Disagreeable,

Last night the Ship Dau-
ntless sailed for Valparaiso There has a fleet
of Ships left for the Islands today the Ottawa
Monteria and several others, There are 4 Mana
wars Man 'o Wars lying here and we can hear the band of
Music every morning at 8 oclock and at
6 oclock in the evening which is very pleasent pleasant
The Ship that arrived yesterday with the Lady
on board has gone in nearer to the to the to the Shore
as she has some Cargo to discharged discharge , There
are more or less Vessels coming or going every
day,

This morning I arose very
early and accompanayed accompanied
Father on Shore to
Market The marketing was all on the ground
It was quite a curiosty curiosity they had every thing
you could mention from there Father went to the
American Ship Chandlery In "Mobile, Her Trade, Commerce and Industries, 1883-4," John Land describes a ship chandler as a port retailer that boat captains relied upon for anything from tools and equipment to food supplies and paper goods 101. and I stop stopped there untill until
he had order ordered what he wished and we then
returned by the way of the Ship California Packet
Captian Captain Gardner the one that has his Wife on
board and got some very nice Cabbages they
are from Valparaiso 7 days Passage bound to
the Islands so we shall have plenty of company
after Breakfast Father went on shore again and
when the Boat returned he sent off 7 men
to go to the Island with us to load the Ship-
and to be discharged when we returned back
here again have discharged the Second Mate
and the boy that run away from Captian Captain
White as he was no use to us, after Dinner
Captian Captain Gardner came on board and left his
Wife and Son while he went on Shore she
appears to be very much of a Lady The Boy
is 6 years old stopped untill until 9 oclock in the
evening Mother is the same

This morning after Breakfast
I went along of the Ship California Packet
A packet ship travels "at regular intervals between two ports, originally for the conveyance of mail, and later also of goods and passengers; a mailboat." In Doane's case, the packet ships could have been the chief means of communication with the mainland Oxford English Dictionary.
and Mrs Gardener
accompanayed accompanied us on Shore
we went to the Market bought a number little
Stores then went to the American Hotel stop there
untill until Father had settled his buisness business had Lu-
nch had some Wine Cake Fruit in a short
time Father came after me we returned on
board after Dinner hove our anchor got under
and set sail for Chincha Island 100 miles
from here have to beat all the way as the
Wind is ahead.

We are still beating a fre-
sh breeze several Sails in sight bound to
Callao 1 Ship and Bark in sight standing the
same way came up with the Ship It was
the Ottawa which left last Wednesday sot set sig
nals The Bark is Obit which left the same
day Mother is confined to her bed with the Fever
again

At 3 oclock AM passed the
Island Asia which is over half way to the Chin
cha have seen the Ottawa and another Ship on
the other tack but bound to the Island
the Steward is cleaning the cabin Windows.

Land in sight and a
fresh breeze the men are busy getting the
anchor and chain up Mother is little better
several sails in sight in sight
on the same
tack at dusk could see the Ship at an
anchor at the Island shortened sail and
keep off dinning the night This morning close
in to the Island Calm. saw a small sail
coming off to us they came along side and
asked Father if he wanted a Pilot Father
told them he gessed guessed he could get along with-
out one they said he would have to pay pilot-
age all the same if he took one or not so
Fathertold them they could on board there now three
they came on board laughing and introduce
ed themselves as Captian Captain of Ship lying at
the Island we had quite a laugh when we
thought it was a Pilot all the time they said
It was the Custom of the Island the Capta-
ins to go off and bring in Ships. Captian Captain Sm-
all was the Pilot The Ship Ottawa and Monteria
came in company with us came at an anchor
at 11 oclock PM at the North Island a great
many Ships here
Harbor Journal

The Island is a Solid Rock
about 150 High and the Guano is upon the top
The way they load the ships is The Ship close
in and the Island and they have a shoot chute
made of Canvass Canvas which leads from the top of
Island into the Ships Hole a distance of 100 feet
and they pore poured the Guano through it. then they
have small Shoot chute for boats to Ballast Ballast consists of any heavy material, such as gravel, sand, metal, water, etc., placed in the hold of a ship to weigh it down in the water and prevent it from capsizing when under sail or in motion. For its trip home from Peru, the Commonwealth used guano as ballast. Ships
The Guano smells something like
there is nothing to be seen olny only a few Huts on
the Island where the laborers that work on
the Guano lived Father has gone on shore
to lett let them know we are ready to take in and
to get a Lighter to Ballast with They gave him
a 20 Ton Lighter and told him he would have
to load with Lighters, when he returned he
brought the Doctor off with him to see Mother
as she is confined to her bed again He fixed
some medicine for her to take said he thought
she would soon get better as it was very heal-
thy here Captian Captain Corner of the Ship James
Corner has his Wife lay but a short distance
from us and there is another Lady which lays
to the other Island about a mile from here.

This morning we hove up our
anchor and hauled in near the Shoots chutes and
have commenced Ballasting Mother is so
she can sit up days with laying down on the
Sofa once in a while, Captian Captain Macfarling of
the Charles Ward has been on board to invite
us on board of his Ship tomorrow to dine as
the Captians Captains that had theirs their Wives were to
be thier there
Father and myselfe myself went I feel very sad
that Mother could not go

A very pleasent pleasant morning tak-
ing in Guano Mother is some better Captian Captain
Corner and Wife Captian Captain Lowell and Wife came
on to call to see Mother and also Captian Captain Genings
of the Ship Arcoal which left New York Harbor
in company with us bound to San Francisco lays
to the middle Island.

This morning Father was going
on board of the Ship Souter JohnyJohnnie
Captian Captain
Small and I went with him as Captian Captain Cam-
el of the Bark Royal Saxton Saxon
Probably the Royal Saxon that arrived at Baltimore on March 16, 1854 Shipping Intelligence. who has his Wi-
fe was stopping on board of the Soutter Johny
as his Bark was under the Shoot chute loading
They have a little Daughter 3 weeks old

dateline.date: Monday May 3thMay 3 fell on a Tuesday in 1853. From the context, it is not clear whether Doane has mistaken the day of the week or the date.

div.p:
Taken in Guano Mother is so
she is up on deck again one Ship in sight
Father has been in after the Glass says it is
the California is getting ready to go out to Pilot
him in she is now at an anchor close to us
there ten boat boats went out to her Captian Captain Gardner
and Mrs Gardner came on board of us in the
evening we were very glad to see her.

Taken in Guano our Ballast
is all out we have to lay here 65 days we have
to Ballast and then lay untill until our turnes comes
to go under the Ships Shoot chute where we can load
in 4 days The Bark Royal Saxton Saxon has sailed
today so you see their there is one of the best Ladies.
Mrs Gardner came on board and spent the after
noon with us and the Little Boy fetched his
Monkey which is a Pet of his and a mischief-
ous mischiev-
ous little thing it is

This morning we went up close
to the Island and then went on board the
California Packet Probably the California Packet that cleared New York Harbor on April 17, 1852 Marine Intelligence. she has a large Cabin
but very plain after dinner Captian Captain Gardner and
Father went on board of Captian Captain Hopkins and
board his Gig Boat which has a very handsome
lining and brought it along side of the Ship
and we got in then we went along side of
the James Corner and took Mrs Corner and
Lowell and then went rowing intending to go
around the Island but had not got far
when it began to breeze up Fresh and we
came back

This morning CaptianCaptain Ga-
rdner sent word for us to be ready to go
rowing we got ready and they came along
side with their boat all trimmed with white
Cushions and white lining trimmed with
red we went rowing around the South Island the one
that have never been disturbed such a quanity quantity
of Birds I never saw in my life they will not
allow you to fire off a Gun on account of the
Birds nor to Capture the Seal when we returned
Mrs Gardner came on board and spent the
day with us in the evening Captian Captain Davis of
the Ship came and spent the evening.

This is a very pleasent pleasant day Cap-
tian Captain Dunbar and Captian Captain Knowels have called
on us this morning Captian Captain Crawford
dinned dined
with us after Dinner Captian Captain and Mrs Gard-
ner came along side and we went and called
on Mrs Lowell found her very much of a La-
dy from there we went on board of the James
Corner was much pleased with Mrs Corner
they have a very nice Cabin and an excell-
ent Cook and Steward which has been with
them 4 years steady then we returned on
board

Pleasent Pleasant day have been on
board of the Packet and spent the day and
while there Captian Captain Corner came on board
and invited us on board of James Corner
the next day to dine

Today we have been on
board of James Corner and there we found
Captian Captain Lowell and Wife Captian Captain Macfarling
Captian Captain Genings
Captian Captain Walker and Mrs
Walker Dine at 2 oclock dine on Turkle TURTLE
served up in 4 different Dishes which we
were not fond of Mother seeing the Boiled
Turkle took it to be veal and eat very
hartyhearty of it we had quite a laugh with
her Dessert was Fruit after Dinner we went
up on the Quarter Deck and the Captians Captains
went out to Pilot in the Ship General Wa-
shington was coming in and also the Bark A barque or bark is "a three-masted vessel with fore- and main-masts square-rigged, and mizenmast ‘fore-and-aft’ rigged" Oxford English Dictionary
Illustration of a Bark, ca. 1870
Picture of a bark ship, ca. 1870
LochliboLoch Libo
Captian Captain Baird which we left in
Acapulco
Captian Captain Crawford was his Pilot
returned on board at 5 oclock

Today we are invited on board
the California Packet to spend the day
as all the Captians Captains and there their Wives are
to be there when father came to tea he
informed us the Ship David had arrived
he had been on board of her Captian Captain Frost
was well had a great deal of trouble after we
left The first Mate shot the Sail Maker and
the Carpenter was conserned concerned in it he left them
there to be sent home in the first Manawar Man-of-war
and bored borrowed a Mate to come to the Island
with is to give him up as soon as his Ship
arrived,

A very pleasent pleasant day have
been rowing around the Island did not stop
any where Captian Captain Frost came and spent the
evening and wanted Mr Frost to go on board
with him as his Mate had left so we are
left without a Mate again.

This is a very pleasent pleasant
day Captian Captain has been along side for us to
go rowing which is all the Pleasure we
have went around to the Middle Island
on board of the Ship Senator
Captian Captain Coffin
and he had a chair made of a Bread Cask
all cushionid cushioned and a very nice chair it was
had a vey nice Cabin but the Captians Captains had
a good deal of sport with him about his
chair from there we went on board of the
Arcoal
Captian Captain Genings we were whip right
up on the Quarter Deck his Cabin was
very much like the Senators from these
we went along side of the James Ward
James Conner and Monterey and invited
them on board of us the next day to dine

Today we have had company
they seemed to enjoye enjoy themselves very much
found them all very pleasent pleasant and agreeable
after Dinner the Captian Captain went out sailing
we played on the Accordan Accordion and sung today
have finished Ballasting and they have taken
the Lighter away saying we cannot load
in boats shall have to wait untill until our
turns comes and go under the Ships Shoot chute ,

This afternoon Mrs Gardner
came along side for us to go on board the
James Corner as Mrs Corner was quite sick
with a servere severe cough I went with them but
mother prefer stopping on board she did not
feel very well and found her quite sick from
there we went on board of the Monterey and
when we return on board Mrs Gardner came
on board and stop to tea with and the Cap-
tians tains went off to see the Bark Croton out
and mother had some good news to tell us
she said the Comadant Commandant had been on board
and left word that we must go around to
the Middle Island the next day and when
Father returned on board he went to see the
Commadant Commandant about it and he told him the
same but would not tell him when we was
to go under the Shoot chute

Today we are taking down
lining and getting ready to go around to the
Middle Island. Captian Captain and Mrs Gardner have
come on board to go around with us to the other
Island after dinner we sot set our Ensign On 18th century ships, the flag (or "colors") was sometimes lowered as a salute or sign of respect to other ships Kemp 534. which is
a signal for the Captians Captains to come on board if
they choose to do so and then we began to heave
the Anchor and before it was hove up there
were 11 Captians Captains came on board with a boats
Crew to assistis assist us set our sail but there was
not much Wind and they put the boats ahead
and towed us around the Island. The Capt-
ians Capt-
ains seemed to enjoyed themselves very much
Captian Captain Coffin was Pilot anchored us close to
Shoot chute after we came at an anchor Captian Captain
Walker came on board and said he fels feels
him-
sefe him -
self very much slighted for not having an
invitation his ship lays on this side

A very pleasant day mother
is quite sick again has caught some cold Father
has gone around the Island to carry some
water on the Island and when he returned
Mrs Gardner came with him and spent the
day and Captian Captain Walker came and took tea
with us and spent the evening.

Fine warm morning Father has
gone for Captian Captain Walker to go around to the Mid
dle Island as Captian Captain Gardner is coming across
d across
to this Island we sot set our Ensign to welcome
them around she came at an Anchor about 12
oclock Father was Pilot she was towed as
there were no wind.

Father took the Gig boat Captains used gig boats to travel back and forth between shore and their ships Folkard 82. in
yesterday and has had her all cleaned and painted
inside and out and mother and myselfe myself have
been making her some cushions and washing
out a few things. The Commadant Commandant and Mr
Mira have been on board bought mother rock-
ing chair, after they went Captian Captain Corner and
Wife
Captian Captain Lowell and Wife came on board
and pretty soon who should we see coming
but Mrs Gardner so they were all here
did not stop but a short time The Clipper
Ship Alboni has arrived Captian Captain Littlefield he
has his Wife with him they close to the California
Packet.

This morning Captian Captain Burgess
of the Clipper Ship Wirlwind Whirlwind has been on board
and spent the dayforenoon with us and insisted so
hard on our coming on board in the afternoon
we could not refuse we went he welcome us
on board of his Ship and of all the hand-
some Cabin his beat all I have ever seen had
two Cabins foreward and after Forward one was
White and Gilt - The after one Black Walnut
Mahogny Mahogany Satin Wood The Furniture was a Sofa
a Ottaman ottoman a Easey Easy Chair and Gentlmans Gentleman's chair Similar to a modern day recliner, a gentleman's chair would have extended for the comfort of the sitter. A desk might be attached to the arm Whiting 48.
and a marble top Center Table cover with Velvet
Plush stop untill 9 oclock o'clock in the evening after
tea Captian Captain Dunbar and Captian Captain Sears came
and spent the evening

This morning the Ship Alboni
has halled hauled in nearer the Shoot chute
Captian Captain Burgess
has been on board and dined with us after
Dinner Captian Captain and Mrs. Gardner came on
board for us to go and called on Mrs. Little
field we got ready and went and found the
other two Ladies there had very nice accomada-
tion accomodation passed around some fruit from there we
we
went on board the Packet and spent the
evening

Today the Market man
has brought us a Goat and little Kid
The Kid is as black as jet so I have a
Pet, The Corker we have on board that is
Corking the Ship, He seenig seeing me pet it very
much told me I must have a Handsomer
Pet and He would make me a present
of a little White lap Dog if I would accept
of it, He finish Corking tonight and
tomorrow goes to Pisco

This morning The Corker
has been on board presented me with the Dog
It is a pretty little thing I can tell you his
Hair is like Silk. he is all White with the ex-
ception of his Ears which are Sammon Salmon
Colar color
He has a very handsome Colar collar on and a
little Bell as big as a thimble. I have given
the Kid away.

Today we are getting ready
to Smoke the Ship as she is full of Rats
This morning the California Packet hauled to
the Bouy, The Bark Laurens has arrived from
San Juan. The Captian Captain has his Wife with him,
Mrs. Gardner and ourselves are to spend the
day on board of the Alboni enjoyed ourselves
much, I stopped on board of the Alboni all
night and mouther mother went on board of the Cali
fornia Packet. Tomorrow afternoon at 5 oclock
we are invited on board of the St Patrick
Captian Captain Portman to a Ball all the American Captians Captains and
their Wives that are to he Island are to be
there

This morning I return
on board of Ship early they had found a
great number of Rats. after Dinner went
on board of the Bark to Call on the Lady
as there has no one call on here her as yet
at 5 oclock The Ladies that are on this
Island were here then started from here
to go on board of the St Patrick. before we
got along side we heard the Music went on
board and was supprised surprised to see the place
first up so handsome on board of a Ship
The quarter which was very large was all
enclosed with Canvass and lined with Ships
Signals all the Chairs and Stools was cover-
ed with Signals also. The Canvass was in
the Center of the Deck the top was Brass
around the edge of it was Guns Bagnets
15 in number Candles burning in them
around the side were covered with Signals
and looped up which formed a very handsome
Chanderleir Chandelier and the lights around the Sides
Here we took the arm of the Captian Captain of the
Ship who escorted us to a Room that had
been fixed expressly for the Ladies. There was
a Sofa Dressing Bureau. Wash Sink Chairs and
Carpet. from there we went on Deck where Dan-
ceing cing room commenced, at 12 oclock we all
marched down to Supper two by two The Table
looked splendi splendid . It would sit 60 People,
I will now tell you what we had. Soups
Roast Pig Roast Turkey Roast Chicken
Roast Beef Roast Lamb.

Boiled Ham Boiled Tongue Tongue was a common food at this time. It is unclear to what sort of tongue Doane refers, but most likely it is lamb or beef. Boiled tongue was prepared by boiling it for 5 to 6 hours and letting it sit over night. Then the skin of the tongue was peeled off and the tongue cut in thin slices The Country Cook Cook Book. Boiled Chickens
Boiled Mutton and all kinds of Green Vegatable.
which was mostly preserved Dersert Dessert . Plum
Puddings Mince Apple Gooseberry Current
Orange Pies. Calfes calf's foot Jelly Calf's foot jelly, commonly made to accompany other foods, was made by boiling the calf's feet, draining the well-done feet through a double silk sieve, adding sugars and spices, and then straining it until transparent Ude.Blanche Man-
ge. Blanche-Mange is made by boiling Carrageen (also known as Irish Moss) then adding milk, lemon, white wine, or anything sweet. This mixture was recommended as a breakfast food for patients with consumption as well as children with scrofulous or "rickety diseases" "Arcana of Science and Art". Fruits, Oranges Apples Banaha Banana
Cherries
Almonds and Raisens raisins Lemon Ade Champeign Champagne
& Waiters, and Wines. Then we returned on Deck
proanade promenade and Danced at 2 oclock. Lemon
Ade, 4 differince different kinds of Cake Cheese and
Mottois. So after this we left in the St Patrick
Boat which was carpeted and Cushioned and
maned manned by his sailors they were dress in White
but in going down the Ladder one of our com-
pany Mrs Gardner made a Miss Step and
fell between the Side and ladder with her
Head downwards but fortunately caught by
the Captians Captains that were standing on the Steps
at the time it was through carelessness as
there was plenty of lights stationed down the
Steps. I like to forgot to mentione mention that there
was one lady Captian Captain Mac Cornets Wife had
a Baby 5 months old and another little Girl
2 years. I thought the poor Women would not
have an opportunity to Dance as she appeare
d to want to very much
fortuneate fortunate for her
the Baby got to sleep and she made the
best of it that is danced once.

This morning Bright and
early Captian Captain Gardner came on board and
brought Mrs Gardner and Walter as He
was going to Haull haul to the Shoot chute She will stop
with us while they are under the Shoot chute . This
morning Father went on Board of the Alboni on
an errand and when he returned informed us
That the first Mate was Stabbed last night by
one of the Sailors. seemed the Mate
ored ordered him
to do something and he did not like it and
stepped up to the Mate and Stabbed him He
is in a Dangerous Situation are to spend the
on board of the Monteria.

This is the Fourth of
July are to spend it on board of the James
Corner The Ladies are all to be there The
Mate of the Alboni is out of Danger. we have
spent a very pleasent pleasant day there has been some
trouble on board of the Ship Hampden, Mrs
Lowell was not there as one of the Captians Captains
sent her on board some late Papers She
was all ready to come out waiting for Cap-
tian tain Lowell when she took up one of the
Papers and the first thing she saw was
the Death of her Aunt her own Mother died
when she was young and this Aunt had bro
-ught her up She took it to heart very much

This morning father has
gone on board of the Bark Lurens Laurens after Mrs
Logan to come and spend the day with us
last evening the California Packet came out
from under the Shoot chute after Dinner I went on
board of the Alboni and spent the day after
noon and when I returned in the afterevening
I found Mrs Gardner had gone on board of
her Ship as they was to sail the next morn=
ing

This morning after Breakfast
we went on board of the California and soon
after we got there Mrs Littlefield came they are
getting under way Father is Pilot we went almost
around to the other Island with them when
they backed Main Yard to let us out. after
Dinner. Mrs Littlefield Mrs Logan and our
selves went around to the other Island to call
on Mrs Bearse of the Ship BeslinBerlin who arrived
last Saturday and was to stop for the other La
dies, The James Corner is to the Buoy Mrs
Comer informed us that Mrs Bearse had gone
on board of the Ship A M Lawrence so we
stop there a short time.

dateline.date: Saturday July 8th At this point, Doane's dates drift out of sync with the calendar until Saturday, July 16.

div.p:
This is a very pleasent pleasant
day have been washing out a few things after
Dinner commenced haulling to the Buoy. Captian Captain
Burgess came on board with a Boats crew and
Captian Captain Hollis sent a Boats crew to assistis assist
us to haul to the Buoy.

Today we have been on board
of the Ship Berlin and spent the day it is a
fine Ship altho although not a Clipper, The James Corner
is under the Shoot chute
loding loading fast. after Dinner
Captian Captain Lowell and Wife and Captian Captain
and Wife came on board and spent the after
-noon and evening

This morning Father has been
around to the Other Island after Mrs Comer
and Mrs Lowell, Captian Captain Lowell has recieved
orders to haul to the Buoy. after Dinner we
all went along side of the Bark and after
Mrs Littlefield also and we went on Shore
to the North Island landed at the Navy
Yard walked up on the Hill where the Ship
whis was under the Shoot chute and they offered us
some seats and we sat down to rest a
few Minuets minutes when Captian Captain Logan came
and called us said they were just haulled hauled
up the ensign on board of the James Cor
ner as she was Loaded we ran down and
all the Ladyes ladies gave her 3 Cheers. Captian Captain
Corner looked up and Wafed Waved his Hand-
Kerchief. We went unto the dry Good Store Typically available at ports, dry goods stores provided goods such as "textile fabrics and related things; articles of drapery, mercery, and haberdashery (as opposed to groceries)" Oxford English Dictionary.
where there were a few Boots Shoes and etc.
they Gave us some very nice Wine
we then went unto onto
Mr. Seraters office. you
would laugh to see him. He is very fleshy
and his Hair is as White as the Snow and
his Face is very red had a Great thick
Pare Pair of Boots all covered with Guano could
not speak a word of English. There was
Captian Captain Sears
Captian Captain Putman
Captian Captain
Calton and Mr. Miro the Agent for the
Sabas Island Vessel so we was going
down to Beach so Old Seraters was
pushing the Captians Captains along to Escort us
when Mother
stepes steps up and takes his Arm
and he looks around and told one of
men to go and get his and they to
him that was laugh for all hands
when we got down to the Beach there
was quite a heavey heavy Surf on the Captians Captains
took us up in theirs their arm and put us
in the Boats wet our Dresses some that
was all Old Serater watched us out of
sight in the evening Captian Captain Sears Captian Captain
Puttman and Captian Captain Littlefield came
and spent the evening about 8 oclock
the Soulter Johnny was Loded Loaded we went
and gave her 3 cheers twice. Mrs. Corner
and Mrs. Lowell stop all night with us

This morning bright and
early we commenced haulling hauling under the Shoot chute
and Captian Captain Coffin haulling hauling to the Buoy
after Breakfast He came on board and took
us on board of the Whirlwind where we are
to Dine all the Ladies were there Dine on
fresh Pork which was very nice. at 4 oclock
we went around to the Middle Island to
called on Mrs Bearse as she was not there
and from there along side of the James
Corner. and left Mrs Corner Mrs Lowell
and Mothey Mother they will stop on board untill
she sailes sails and I returned on board of
the Alboni as I am to stopped there while
We am under the Shoot chute

This morning after
Breakfast Captian Captain Puttman came along
side with Mrs Logan to take us on board
of the James Corner to see them offt off We
stopped on board untill she was ready to
let go of the Buoy. Mrs Lowell and Mother
returned on board of the Berlin with Mrs
Bearse, Mrs Logan spent the day on board
of the Alboni, Captian Captain Littlefield has a
very nice sail Boat and after Dinner we
went sailing

This morning I returned
of on board of our Ship again Mrs. Little-
field went on board with me to see us off
as we sail as soon as Father
get gets his
Papers from the Island we let go of
the Buoy at 12 o'clock there was a num
ber of Captians Captains on board Captian Captain Wash-
born
Captian Captain Logan
Captian Captain Sears
Captian Captain
Puttman
Captain Captain Littlefield
Captian Captain Frost
and when we got around to the other
Island Captian Captain Hooper came up along
side of in his sail Boat with a number
of other Captians Captains and when the Captians Captains
left us they all got into his Boat and whe
n they got off some ways they gave us 3
Cheers and we answered them Captians Captain Was
laughing is going down to Calloa Callao with us
He goes direct from the Island with his
Ship, There is a fine Breeze and Fair

This is a Wet foggy morn-
ing and not much Wind can see Callao
and Shipping Plain. The James Corner and
the Monteria are there 6 oclock came at an
anchor before our Sails were furled Captian Captain
Corner and Wife came on board and spen
t the evening with us after tea Captian Captain
Lowell and Wife came and spent the evening

This morning Breakfast The
Sailors that we shipped at
Calloa Callao was
discharged at 9 oclock We all meet
on board of the James Corner and all
started from there on Shore stopped at the
Golden Ball Hotel at Callao
untill until the
Cars went which was at 10 oclock then
we went up to Lima went to the princi
ple Hotel and engaged a room then
went out about the City Things are
very high here I did not see much
about Lima worth seeing returned back
to
Callo Callao in the two oclock train went
to the Hotel and dined, We have a
private Dining by ourselves, We stopped
at the best Hotel at Calloa Callao and have
the best room Floor brick Cot Bedstead
with a old Bed covered with a common
bed Spread Wash Stand Cheap Look-
ing Glass and a few Wooden Chairs
returned on at night

This is a pleasant day
have been on Shore done some shoping shopping
The James Corner
sailes sails tonight for
Baltimore We shall all meet at Baltimore
The California Packet The Monteria and
ourselves.

This morning our Stewa
rd came to Father and wanted to go on
Shore we have thought that he intended
to run away but He promised that
he would be down to the Mould at
9 oclock, So Father let him go. Father
has shipped a First mate and we take
Mr Brown our Carpenter for Second Mate
He has gone on Shore on liberaty liberty after
Dinner Mrs Lowell came on board
and spent the afternoon but did not
stop to Tea as Captian Captain Lowell came
along side but could not stop as he
had some writing to do so they went on
board just as they shoved off from the
side of the Ship I saw our boat coming
I heard Mr Brown talking singing and
laughing I knew He was drunk. The
Mate came off with them His name is
Bailey Mr. Brown was Stering Steering when he got
along side he wanted to know what Boat
that was and Hailed to Captian Captain
Lowill Lowell
to stop but they took no notice of him
He came on board went night to Mother
took hold of her hand and says Oh
Mudder I am so glad to see you then
He came to me and I run ran from him
he says Louisa dont you run from me
I wont hurt you. and then say he if
my Captian Captain tells me to go to the Main
truck I will go or whatever he tells me
to do I will do it if it cost me my
life then he went out on deck went up
to the Mate and says Mr Bailey you
need not trouble yourselfe about seeing
the things got out of the Boat I will at
tend to that and he drove him off. He
told Barney if he lost his Files overboar-
d he would drown him after the things
were all out off of the Boat he came to
the door and says now Mudder I am
going to Bed and I will be all right in
the morning.

This morning are getting
ready for Sea our Crew are all on board
our old Steward we have never seen since
he went on Shore has run away for good
have Shipped another one he has come on
board Durnk Drunk made out to get to the
Galley He told the Cook to ask Mother
if she would excuse him Mrs. Lowell
is on board when we began to heave up
the anchor their Mate came after her
and took her on board of their Ship
our anchor is up our Sails are set and
we are headed towards Home which
is a happy day for us after being absent
about 12 months

We have a head Wind
beating Sence Since we left Callao we have had
but very little Fair Wind therefore have
made but very little progress This morn
ing saw a Ship bound the same way
standing on the other tack when we came
up with found it was the Colchus
Captian Captain Higgins left Callo Callao the same day
we did when we got abreast of her we
tack and now then for a Beat think we
have a vey very good Crew they appear to
be active and ready for a call and
a good Steward still in company with
the Ship

We have a fair Wind
althou although very little Studding sot set
The Colchus
is in sight astern have caught a num-
ber of Cape Pigions Pigeons my Dog is very
fond of them The Sailors are all busy
attending to Ship Duty. The Ship is Just
in sight astern

Wind ahead and
blowing fresh at 6 oclock took in the
light Sails at 2 oclock in the night it
blowed vey very hard and reefed down the
Main and Mizen mizzen Topsails which was
the only sail we had sot set
Mother and
myselfe myself got up and went to door to look
out and first thing we saw was the
Stweard coming in buttoning up Jack-
et and his Cap tied under his chin
and went out again Mother called
him and asked him where he was
going He turns round and says Mam Ma'am
I am going to help reef Topsails She
told him he had better stop in the
Cabin and look out for the things
He said he was alway used to help
reef Topsails but he would stop in
the Cabin did not sleep much as
it blow very hard and she rooled rolled very
heavey heavy The Steward did not leave the
Cabin for the night

The Wind still con
tinues head and blowing fresh this
morning at 8 oclock tacked Ship mother
layed on the Furl in the lower Cabin
as the Guano smeelt smelt very strong in
the State Room when the Ship fetch
a heavey heavy
learch lurch and way came a
Box of Medicine out of the Store Room
m broke several Bottles and the
contents went all over the Bed cloths clothes
after supper there came a Gust
of Wind blew out three Cloths out
of the Gib it sounded just like
a Gun going offt off

We have a fresh
breeze Fair going 8 miles an hour
Studding sot on both sides thick un
pleasent pleasant weather and Squally Today
is Father Birth day 44 years of Age

Winds still continues
us Fair have killed our large Hog

Wind Fair at 11
oclock breezed up and blowed very hard
took in all sail but the Fore and
Main Topsail and those were close
it look dreay dreary and dismal enough
the sea running mountains high
snow and Hail Squalls have one
man lay up fell down on deck and
hurt him,

Today we have a Fair
Wind had it Fair for the last forright fortnight
has brought us around Cape Horn in
a hurry after Dinner it commenced blowing
took in all sail but the Fore Main Mizen mizzen
topsails those were double reefed the Wind
increasing all the time at dusk it was
a perfect Gale took in all sail but the
Fine Topsail There was a heavey heavy cross sea
the deck were full of Water all the time
2 men at the Wheel and very cold the
Sailors stopped in the Entry The Goat and
Fowl was put into Mr. Browns Brown's Room for
ward.

This morning at 6 oclock
commenced making Sail The Wind subsid-
ed at 4 oclock The Steward is sick after
Breakfast he came in and went to work
This afternoon it is quite Smooth.

This is a pleasent pleasant day
altho although we have a head Wind This morn
ing when I arose there was a Brigg in
sight ahead bound the other way She keep
off and came close to us showed Signals
English after Breakfast have a Vessel
Steam standing the same way we are
is gaining on us fast the Bark it is none
of our Fleet unless it is the Black Squall
who left Callao the day we arrived have
caught several Albatrosses

Wind ahead blowing Fresh
Is is a warm pleasent pleasant
morng morning
Mother and
myselfe myself have been out on deck all mornig morning
Father has caught 4 large Albatrosses and
The Cook asked him if he wanted them for
any particular use he told him no he said
the Sailor wanted them cooked for their dinners
have some brought in the Cabin said they
were very nice but I did not tasite taste of them

Fair Wind blowing Fresh
Studding sot set in both Father is busy making
a canvass trunk evening Mother and myselfe myself
have been busy making a Shoe Bag my
Dog is some Sea Sick not so playfull playful as
in general at 12 oclock today was in the
Latitiude of 30 = 04 South have made 204
miles distance the last 24 hour which is
going fast

This is a pleasent pleasant day
fair Wind Studding sot set today have noticed
the Mainmast was rotten have been putting
a spar to lash it what they call Fishing at 4
oclock a Sail appeared in Sight ahead
bound the other Father keep off to speak her
when we got up with her found it was a
Frenchmen The Brigg Louisa of spoke
her He could not speake English showed
own Longitude but they did not show theres theirs
their were sevel several Ladies on Board. He
dip his Colars colors three times to us and
we answer him. We are in the Latitude
of 22 = 57 South and Longitude 33 = 40 a Short
distance North of Rio Janeiro de Janeiro .

Wind continues the
same fair and a fresh Breeze. This morn
ing when I arose there was a Brigg in Sightt
ahead bound in the other way A Frenchmen
Father has caught a large Dolphin had
it cooked for Breakfast it was quite a
treat today have killed the Goat as she
had eaten up all her Hay and Corn and
would eat no bread nor nothing else was
oblidge to kill her but was very loth to
part with her as she gave us milk enough
for our Coffee and Tea, The Cook killed
her he told Mother he cut her throat
and the first thing he knew She sprung
out of his arms and jumped on the Forecastle
Deck. Mother asked him why he did not
cut her head right off. he said he want
ed to give her a chance to think before
she died A Brigg in sight bound the
other way a Portuguese showed Longitudes
The Sailors are all busey busy
taring tearing down rigging

This is the first day of
the month and comes in with a beautifull beautiful
Fair Wind altho although
unpleasent unpleasant weather rainey rainy
we are now in the South East Tade Trade Winds
The sailors have had liberty to wash their
cloths clothes they have been down in the Lea
scuppers washing. I set out on deck between
one of the showers and we looked like
a Manawar Man 'o War
cloths clothes hung up all around
the rigging had a very ruff rough night the
wind blew very hard for a short time
last night when they were making sail
Mr Brown sung out to Belay when the
first Mate steps up and sawy I am
looking out for the sail Mr Brown says
Is here too He is a Sweed Swede and speak
broken English I laugh to hear him
sometimes are in the Latitude of 13=48.

This is a pleasent pleasant day
very warm are in the Latitude of 4=50
North and Longitude crossed the line
last Saturday after Breakfast saw

more to the Westland showed Engign ensign an
